_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Fluid Power Valve and Hose Fitting Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is established for Gardner Denver Petroleum & Industrial

Pumps (GDI-P&IP) Aledo facility. The RMP is developed in accordance with the United States

Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA) Chemical Accident Prevention regulations 40 CFR

Part 68 with Program 2 requirements for facilities were flammable endpoint for a worst-case

release assessment exceeds the distance to public receptors. The purpose of this RMP document

is to assist with the prevention of accidental releases of flammable substances that can cause

harm to the public, facility employees and the environment.

The GDI-P&IP Aledo facility stores Liquefied Petroleum Gas (propylene, CAS No.115-07-1) for

use in pump plunger manufacturing operations exceeding Table 3: ?68.130 - List of Regulated

Flammable Substances and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention of 10,000

pounds. The facility maintains two 1,990-gallon tanks for a total potential capacity of 3,980 gallons

(17,034 pounds). The propylene system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with

federal, state, and local laws.

Risk is defined by the combination of the probability or likelihood that the process will experience

an event and the consequences, impact, or severity of the event. Each process assumes some

element of risk, however, when risk management techniques are applied to monitor and track

events with the potential to impact operations, the overall risk can be minimized at the facility.

This facility complies with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) requirements for LP-Gas

storage, and will adhere to applicable federal, state, and local laws. In the event of an emergency,

it is our policy to notify the Fire Department and request assistance in respond to an emergency.

The worst-case scenario evaluated is failure of the storage tank system when filled to the greatest

amount allowed (88% at 20?C), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting dista

nce to the

endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint. The

alternative release scenario analyzed is a break in a 0.25-inch diameter hose, leading to a 240-

minute release inside the Spray Room and subsequent vapor cloud explosion. The resulting

distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the

endpoint.

The facility has no reported accidents involving propylene that caused deaths, injuries, property

or environmental damage, evacuations, or required sheltering in place orders.

The system is equipped with safety measures to prevent accidental release and equipment to

detect a release. In the event of an emergency involving the propylene system, it is policy to notify

the Fire Department and request assistance responding to the emergency. We will coordinate our

response plan with the fire department and have the fire department inspect the propylene system

and conducted joint exercises.
